bibl.title: Letter from Jessie Daniel Ames to Philip Showalter Hench, July 24, 1942

div1.p: Jessie Ames writes that Hench may keep the fever charts as soon as she gets them back and can send them to him. She thinks the War Department does not have a complete dossier on her husband, and attributes this to carelessness.

div1.head: Letter from Jessie Daniel Ames to Philip Showalter Hench, July 24, 1942
div1.opener:
WILL W. ALEXANDER
EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR
C. H. TOBIAS
ASSOCIATE DIRECTOR
M. ASHBY JONES, HONORARY PRESIDENT
HOWARD W. ODUM, PRESIDENT
CHARLES S. JOHNSON, FIRST VICE PRESIDENT
MRS. W. A. NEWELL, SECOND VICE PRESIDENT
RUFUS E. CLEMENT, THIRD VICE PRESIDENT
EMILY H. CLAY
SECRETARY-ASST. TREASURER
KENDALL WEISIGER
TREASURER
Commission on Interracial Cooperation
INCORPORATED
710 STANDARD BUILDING
Atlanta, Georgia
July 24, 1942
R. B. ELEAZER
EDUCATIONAL DIRECTOR
MRS. JESSIE DANIEL AMES
DIRECTOR OF FIELD WORK
R. P. NEBLETT, JR.
FIELD SECRETARY
JACKSON, MISSISSIPPI
Dr. Phillip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minn.
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
You did not have to put up an argument to convince me that I would
want to contribute the Yellow Fever charts to you. As soon as I
get them back I will return them to you, keeping them only long
enough to insert Case #1 - Kissinger. You may have them all or you
my select the ones you want and send the rest back here. I would
like some of the phostats to put in the portfolio just to keep that
record complete. On the other hand if you do not want all these
originals, the ones you return can serve that purpose.

It seems to me from the general tone of your questions and some of
your observations that the record of the only really important result
of the Spanish American War is largely dependent upon memories of
those living but not present when the experiment was conducted; and
the observations and deductions of the dead who did not support their
statements with factual evidence. At least I am sure that the failure
of the War Department to have a complete dossier on my husband was
not premeditated. It was carelessness. Also I can understand some-
thing of Dr. Kean's stubborn insistence on his stand as to those who
helped and were deserving recognition. He had spoken with authority and
without much evidence. When evidence was adduced that indicated he was
not after all omniscient, he just could not re-open the case. He would
be admitting that maybe he had made other mistakes.

I had no idea that those charts were the original ones. I knew that
they were so marked but I thought that was a slip. It would never have
entered my head that any such carelessness could characterize the
handling of the War Department or any other establishment of the
Government, except some of those established by this administration.

I promise you that if my sister-in-law does not give you satisfaction,
I will see her myself. I have a pursuasive tongue and I have been
known to be convincingly humble.

If when you get settled in the Army hospital you have the time and the
inclination I should like for you to write me and tell me just how you
got started on this project. It is not exactly in line with your
special interests as far as I am able to judge.

If you recall anything else in my files that you would like to add to
your collection, I am glad it is to be kept in the Mayo Clinic until
you realize your plan of the Museum, I will gladly send it to you. I
am enclosing the Laredo report about which you asked. That is, you
asked whether or not I had a copy of it. I think you would not have
done this had you not wanted it to study or to add to your records.

With the sincerest wishes for your happiness in serving in the Army,
I am

closer.seg:
P.S. The Times-Picayune photostat has not come. I am going to be in New
Orleans this fall and if it has not been sent you by them, I will see to
it in person.
